newsitem.title: UK: LME aluminium sustains run-up, copper falters.
newsitem.headline: LME aluminium sustains run-up, copper falters.

text.p: The LME's two top contracts went their separate ways on Wednesday afternoon as aluminium extended morning gains while copper ceded half of its earlier run-up.
Three months aluminium carved out fresh highs over the $1,400 mark, touching a peak of $1,411, before closing $39 higher at $1,406.
Copper on the other hand struggled to edge back above the key $1,970 level after hitting $1,990 in the morning, ending the afternoon kerb $16 higher at $1,976.
Short-covering and fund and trade buying boosted both markets on Wednesday morning with most of the fund activity seen in aluminium, floor traders said.
Aluminium was able to absorb a patch of producer selling but copper lost its steam as miner selling and profit-taking pounded the highs, traders said.
Analysts, however, see more room for gains in both markets.
"I think there's potential for more short-covering in both copper and aluminium," said William Adams, analyst at broker Rudolf Wolff.
Trades say further LME stock draws are expected in aluminium while copper inventories have already slid by more than 100,000 tonnes since the end of August.
There was, however, a slight weakening in copper's premium of cash metal over three months material, which edged down to $30 from $35 on Tuesday and $40 the day before.
Many of the other metals tried higher levels along with the two leaders in the morning, but like copper were unable to sustain them.
Nickel finished only $15 higher at $7,175 after peaking at $7,230, while lead closed the kerb $5 stronger at $735 after touching $741.
Tin ended $5 weaker at $5,985 and zinc lost 50 cents to $1,024.50.
